title: Rewrite Graph view with proper dependency visualization
description:
# Rewrite Graph View with Proper Dependency Visualization

## Current Implementation Analysis

### Backend (handlers.rs:289-470)
- Loads all issues, builds dependency graph via topological sort (BFS)
- Groups nodes by level based on dependency depth
- Fixed grid positions: left-to-right per level, top-to-bottom for levels
- Static SVG with positions calculated server-side (~180 lines)

### Frontend (graph.html)
- Static SVG rendered server-side via Askama template
- Type filters (epic, feature, bug, task, chore)
- Expand/collapse buttons for epics with children
- In-page JavaScript (~110 lines, not modular TypeScript)

## Problems with Current Implementation

### Layout Issues
1. Fixed grid layout doesn't scale with many nodes (horizontal overflow)
2. No edge-crossing minimization - lines overlap confusingly
3. All nodes shown at once is overwhelming for large projects
4. Expand/collapse doesn't re-layout (just hides nodes in place)

### Interactivity Limitations
1. No pan/zoom for large graphs
2. No node dragging for manual repositioning
3. Static positions calculated once on server load

### Visual Issues
1. Edge arrows overlap nodes when dense
2. Straight lines cross over other nodes
3. No distinction between dependency types (parent-child vs blocks)

### Data Model Confusion
1. Mixes parent-child relationships with blocking dependencies
2. Dot-notation parsing (nacre-3hd.1) for implicit parent-child is fragile

---

## Proposed Approach: Simplified Hierarchical Tree

**Recommendation**: Don't try to visualize all dependency types in one graph. Instead:

### Phase 1: Epic Tree View (Simple)
- Show epics as collapsible tree nodes (like file explorer)
- Children nested under parent epics
- Click to expand/collapse
- Status indicators (colored dots)
- Link to issue detail on click

**Benefits**: Simple, performant, clear hierarchy

### Phase 2: Dependency Overlay (Optional)
- On hover/focus, show which issues block/are blocked by selected issue
- Highlight edges only for selected node
- Avoids visual clutter of showing all edges at once

---

## Implementation Options

### Option A: HTML/CSS Tree (Recommended)
- Use `<ul>/<li>` with CSS for indentation
- Collapsible via existing list.ts toggle pattern
- No external libraries needed
- Server-side rendered, progressive enhancement

### Option B: D3.js Force-Directed
- Dynamic layout, pan/zoom
- Better for complex graphs
- Adds ~100KB dependency
- More complex to implement

### Option C: Dagre/ELK Layered Layout
- Proper DAG algorithm, minimizes crossings
- Requires JS library
- Good middle ground

---

## Suggested Implementation (Option A)

1. **Remove current SVG-based graph** (~180 lines backend, ~110 lines JS)
2. **Create tree template** similar to epics.html structure
3. **Reuse list.ts** expand/collapse logic
4. **Add to navigation.ts** for keyboard nav (j/k to move, Enter to expand)
5. **Filter by status** (open only, all, etc.)

### Data Structure
```
Epic 1
├── Task 1.1 (open)
├── Task 1.2 (in_progress)
└── Task 1.3 (closed)
Epic 2
└── Feature 2.1
    ├── Task 2.1.1
    └── Bug 2.1.2
Standalone Task (no parent)
```

### Blocked-by Indicator
- Small icon/badge showing "blocked by X" count
- Click to see blockers in tooltip or side panel

---

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Tree view shows epics with expandable children
- [ ] Status indicated visually (color dot or badge)
- [ ] Keyboard navigation works (j/k/Enter)
- [ ] Filter by issue type
- [ ] Click navigates to issue detail
- [ ] Responsive (no horizontal overflow)
- [ ] Blocked issues have visual indicator

title: Fix EventType enum to match bd activity output
description:
## Problem
Avg Cycle Time shows 0 because Activity events aren't parsed correctly.

## Root Cause
The `EventType` enum in `src/beads.rs` uses incorrect serialization names:

| bd outputs | Rust expects |
|------------|--------------|
| `create` | `created` |
| `status` | `status_changed` |
| `update` | `updated` |

Because of this mismatch, all activities deserialize with the default `Created` type, so `StatusChanged` events (which contain `new_status`) are never recognized.

## Fix
Update the `#[serde(rename)]` attributes in the `EventType` enum (line ~191 in beads.rs):
- `StatusChanged` should be `#[serde(rename = "status")]`
- `Created` should be `#[serde(rename = "create")]`
- `Updated` should be `#[serde(rename = "update")]`

Or change the enum-level attribute from `rename_all = "kebab-case"` to match bd's actual output.

## Problem
The current connector lines on /graph are straight/angular. They should be more fluid and curved for better visual appeal.

## Precise Context

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<task>
  <instructions>
    <summary>Replace angular connector lines with smooth curved lines on /graph</summary>
    <objective>
      Connector lines between nodes in the org-chart tree should flow smoothly 
      with curves instead of sharp 90-degree angles. The visual result should 
      feel organic and polished.
    </objective>
    <constraints>
      - Must work with existing flexbox-based tree layout (flex-wrap for multi-row)
      - Must support all themes (uses --border-color CSS variable)
      - Must highlight on hover (accent color on path)
      - Performance: CSS-only preferred, but SVG acceptable if needed
    </constraints>
  </instructions>

  <context>
    <tree root="frontend/">
        frontend/
        ├── public/
        │   ├── style.css          (main styles - org-tree section)
        │   └── app.js             (compiled JS)
        ├── src/
        │   └── modules/
        │       └── graph.ts       (epic selector JS, may need updates)
        └── templates/
            └── graph.html         (page template)
    </tree>

    <files>
      <file path="frontend/public/style.css" mode="slice" lines="2935-3100" note="org-tree styles"/>
      <file path="frontend/templates/graph.html" mode="full"/>
      <file path="src/templates.rs" mode="slice" lines="107-165" note="render_html generates ul/li structure"/>
    </files>
  </context>

  <current-implementation>
    <structure>
      HTML: div.org-tree > ul > li > a.org-node + ul > li...
      Connectors: CSS ::before pseudo-elements with border-left (vertical lines)
      Layout: Flexbox with flex-wrap for multi-row display
    </structure>
    
    <connector-css>
      /* Vertical line from child to parent level */
      .org-tree li::before {
          border-left: 1px solid var(--border-color);
          height: 1em;
      }
      
      /* Vertical line from parent to children container */
      .org-tree ul ul::before {
          border-left: 1px solid var(--border-color);
          height: 1em;
      }
    </connector-css>
  </current-implementation>

  <approaches>
    <approach name="CSS border-radius curves">
      <description>Add border-radius to L-shaped connectors using ::before/::after</description>
      <pros>Pure CSS, theme-aware, simple</pros>
      <cons>Limited curve control, complex for wrapped layouts</cons>
      <example>
        .org-tree li::before {
            border-left: 1px solid var(--border-color);
            border-bottom: 1px solid var(--border-color);
            border-radius: 0 0 0 12px; /* curve bottom-left corner */
        }
      </example>
    </approach>
    
    <approach name="SVG path overlay">
      <description>Generate SVG paths with bezier curves via JavaScript</description>
      <pros>Full curve control, can handle complex layouts</pros>
      <cons>Requires JS coordination, more complex</cons>
      <example>
        // Calculate positions and draw:
        <path d="M x1,y1 Q cx,cy x2,y2" stroke="var(--border-color)"/>
      </example>
    </approach>
    
    <approach name="CSS clip-path with path()">
      <description>Use clip-path: path() for curved shapes</description>
      <pros>CSS-only with bezier support</pros>
      <cons>Browser support, complex syntax</cons>
    </approach>
  </approaches>

  <guidance>
    <role>Frontend developer with CSS expertise</role>
    <style>
      - Prefer CSS-only if achievable
      - Keep hover states working (accent color highlight)
      - Test with different tree depths and wrapped layouts
      - Maintain visual consistency with design system
    </style>
    <recommendation>
      Start with CSS border-radius approach on ::before/::after elements.
      If the wrapped flexbox layout makes pure CSS too complex, 
      consider a hybrid approach with minimal JS to calculate positions.
    </recommendation>
  </guidance>
</task>
```

- [ ] Lines work correctly with the current tree layout
- [ ] Curves adapt to node positions
- [ ] Works in all themes (light/dark)
- [ ] Hover highlight still works on connector paths

// Map issue_id to first in_progress timestamp

## Tradeoffs: include_str! vs include_dir!

| Aspect | include_str! (current) | include_dir! |
|--------|----------------------|---------------------|
| Lines of code | ~80 | ~30 |
| Compile-time safety | File existence checked | File existence checked |
| Runtime lookup | None | HashMap lookup |
| Adding new files | Edit Rust code | Just add file |
| Type safety | `&'static str` | Runtime `.contents_utf8()` |
